title: Isaiah Chapter 40 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 40 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 40 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 40.

questions.question: Who is commanded to comfort the people in Isaiah 40:1?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:1 states, 'Comfort ye, comfort ye my people, saith your God.' indicating that God commands comfort for His people.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 40:3, where does the voice cry to prepare the way of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: In the wilderness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:3 says, 'The voice of him that crieth in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the LORD.'

questions.question: What happens to every valley and mountain according to Isaiah 40:4?
options: Every valley shall be exalted and every mountain and hill made low
Every valley shall be destroyed and mountains increased
The valleys and mountains remain the same
Mountains shall be exalted and valleys made low
questions.correctAnswer: Every valley shall be exalted and every mountain and hill made low
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:4 states, 'Every valley shall be exalted, and every mountain and hill shall be made low.'

questions.question: What will all flesh see together according to Isaiah 40:5?
questions.correctAnswer: The glory of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:5 states, 'And the glory of the LORD shall be revealed, and all flesh shall see it together.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 40:8 says the word of God shall fade like grass and flowers.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:8 says the grass withereth and the flower fadeth, but the word of our God shall stand forever, so it does not fade.

questions.question: Who is described as feeding his flock like a shepherd in Isaiah 40:11?
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:11 says, 'He shall feed his flock like a shepherd...,' referring to the Lord.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 40:12, who measured the waters in the hollow of His hand?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:12 asks, 'Who hath measured the waters in the hollow of his hand...?' referring to the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 40:15 compares nations to 'a drop of a bucket' and 'small dust of the balance.'
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:15 states, 'Behold, the nations are as a drop of a bucket, and are counted as the small dust of the balance.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 40:18, what question is asked about God?
options: To whom will ye liken God?
questions.correctAnswer: To whom will ye liken God?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:18 asks, 'To whom then will ye liken God? or what likeness will ye compare unto him?'

questions.question: What does Isaiah 40:22 say God sits upon?
questions.correctAnswer: The circle of the earth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:22 states, 'It is he that sitteth upon the circle of the earth.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 40:31: 'But they that wait upon the LORD shall renew their ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: strength
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:31 states, 'But they that wait upon the LORD shall renew their strength.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 40:26, what does God call by name?
questions.correctAnswer: The stars
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:26 says, 'He calleth them all by names by the greatness of his might,' referring to the host of stars.

questions.question: Isaiah 40:27 says Israel complains that what is hidden from the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Their way
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:27 says, 'My way is hid from the LORD,' showing Israel’s complaint.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 40:29 says God gives power to the faint and increases strength to those who have no might.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:29 states, 'He giveth power to the faint; and to them that have no might he increaseth strength.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 40:19, what does the goldsmith do to the graven image?
questions.correctAnswer: Spreadeth it over with gold
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:19 states, 'The workman melteth a graven image, and the goldsmith spreadeth it over with gold.'

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 40 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 40 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling weak and discouraged in their spiritual walk. Based on Isaiah 40, what biblical truth would you share to encourage them?
options: God gives strength to the faint and increases power to the weak
They must rely solely on their own strength to overcome
Only youth have the energy to serve God effectively
Strength comes through material wealth and success
questions.correctAnswer: God gives strength to the faint and increases power to the weak
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:29-31 teaches that God provides strength to those who are weary and increases the power of those who lack might, encouraging believers to trust in His renewing power.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 40 teach us about trusting God's understanding when life feels confusing?
options: God’s understanding is beyond searching and He never grows tired
We must figure everything out ourselves
God only reveals understanding to the wise
questions.correctAnswer: God’s understanding is beyond searching and He never grows tired
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:28 highlights God's everlasting nature and infinite understanding, reassuring believers to trust in Him even when circumstances are unclear.

questions.question: A believer is anxious about the future and unsure if God sees their needs. What encouragement from Isaiah 40 would you offer?
options: God calls each star by name and is mighty in power
God is too busy to notice individual needs
The future depends on human effort alone
Only the strong are noticed by God
questions.correctAnswer: God calls each star by name and is mighty in power
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:26 describes God’s intimate knowledge and power over creation, reminding believers that He cares deeply for them and is in control.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 40 teach humility in relation to human achievements?
options: All nations are like a drop of a bucket and less than nothing before God
Pride is encouraged as a sign of success
God depends on human strength to rule
questions.correctAnswer: All nations are like a drop of a bucket and less than nothing before God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:15-17 emphasizes God's incomparable greatness and the insignificance of human powers, teaching believers to walk humbly before Him.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 40 teach about God's faithfulness to His promises?
options: The word of our God shall stand forever
Promises can be broken to suit circumstances
Human promises are more reliable than God's
questions.correctAnswer: The word of our God shall stand forever
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:8 assures believers that God's word is eternal and unchanging, encouraging trust and obedience in His promises.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels overwhelmed by trials and wonders how to persevere. How does Isaiah 40 counsel endurance?
options: Those who wait on the LORD shall renew their strength and not grow weary
Endurance depends only on personal willpower
Giving up is sometimes the best choice
Trials are signs of God's abandonment
questions.correctAnswer: Those who wait on the LORD shall renew their strength and not grow weary
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:31 teaches that trusting and waiting on God renews strength and enables believers to persevere without fainting.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 40 encourage believers in the practice of evangelism?
options: Lift up your voice with strength and proclaim, 'Behold your God!' to the cities of Judah
Only priests should proclaim God's word
Sharing the gospel should be done only in private
questions.correctAnswer: Lift up your voice with strength and proclaim, 'Behold your God!' to the cities of Judah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:9 encourages believers to boldly proclaim the good news of God’s salvation to others, emphasizing active witness.

questions.question: What lesson about God’s care is given through the image of a shepherd in Isaiah 40?
options: God feeds and gently leads His flock, carrying the lambs in His arms
Believers must fend for themselves completely
Shepherding is a human responsibility alone
questions.correctAnswer: God feeds and gently leads His flock, carrying the lambs in His arms
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:11 uses the shepherd metaphor to illustrate God's tender care and guidance, reassuring believers of His personal love.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 40, human life and beauty are temporary like grass and flowers, but God's word endures forever.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:6-8 explains that human life is transient like grass and flowers, which wither, but God's word remains eternal.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 40 teaches that God's power is limited because He needed counsel to make decisions.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:13-14 stresses that no one directs or counsels God; His wisdom and power are self-sufficient and unmatched.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 40 says that God sits upon the circle of the earth and the inhabitants are like ________.
questions.correctAnswer: grasshoppers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:22 describes the inhabitants of the earth as grasshoppers compared to God’s sovereign position above the earth.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 40 instruct believers about dealing with fear and doubt when sharing their faith?
options: Lift up your voice with strength and be not afraid
Only share faith with those who agree with you
Fear is a sign to stop sharing
questions.correctAnswer: Lift up your voice with strength and be not afraid
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:9 encourages believers to boldly proclaim God's message without fear, promoting courageous evangelism.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 40 teach about humility in relation to idolatry and human inventions?
options: Idols are made by human hands and cannot compare to God
Making idols is a sign of wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Idols are made by human hands and cannot compare to God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:18-20 points out the futility of idols crafted by humans, contrasting them with the incomparable living God.

questions.question: What practical wisdom about stewardship and generosity can be learned from Isaiah 40’s depiction of God’s sovereignty over creation?
options: Since God controls all things, believers should trust Him with their resources and give generously
We must hoard resources because God’s provision is limited
Only the wealthy are responsible for generosity
questions.correctAnswer: Since God controls all things, believers should trust Him with their resources and give generously
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:12-15 reveals God’s complete control over creation, encouraging believers to trust Him and act with generosity and good stewardship.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 40 encourage believers to respond when feeling forgotten by God?
options: Remember that God is everlasting, never weary, and fully aware of their situation
Accept that God has abandoned them
Stop praying because God does not listen
Rely on others instead of God
questions.correctAnswer: Remember that God is everlasting, never weary, and fully aware of their situation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:27-28 reminds believers that God is eternal and attentive, offering reassurance when they feel neglected or unseen.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 40 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 40.

questions.question: In Isaiah 40:3, the phrase "Prepare ye the way of the LORD" is a typological foreshadowing of which New Testament figure?
questions.correctAnswer: John the Baptist
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:3 describes a voice crying in the wilderness to prepare the way of the Lord, which the New Testament identifies with John the Baptist preparing the way for Jesus (cf. Matthew 3:3).

questions.question: Isaiah 40:6-8 uses the imagery of grass and flowers to illustrate what theological concept?
options: The fleeting nature of human life
questions.correctAnswer: The fleeting nature of human life
questions.explanation: Verses 6-8 contrast the transient nature of flesh as grass and flowers with the enduring word of God, emphasizing human mortality versus divine permanence.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Isaiah 40:4 with the phrases "Every valley shall be exalted, and every mountain and hill shall be made low"?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:4 employs parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, by balancing exaltation of valleys with the lowering of mountains to express leveling and preparation for God's coming.

questions.question: The statement in Isaiah 40:12 about measuring waters in the hollow of His hand demonstrates what aspect of God's nature?
questions.correctAnswer: Omnipotence and sovereignty over creation
questions.explanation: Verse 12 portrays God as the supreme Creator with unlimited power, able to measure the vast waters and heavens, highlighting His omnipotence.

questions.question: Isaiah 40:18 and 40:25 both ask, "To whom then will ye liken God?" This rhetorical question primarily serves to emphasize what theological truth?
options: The incomparable and unique nature of God
questions.correctAnswer: The incomparable and unique nature of God
questions.explanation: Both verses use rhetorical questioning to stress that no earthly likeness or idol can compare to the one true God, emphasizing His uniqueness.

questions.question: In Isaiah 40:22, the description of God sitting upon "the circle of the earth" and stretching out the heavens as a curtain is an example of what kind of ancient Near Eastern imagery?
questions.correctAnswer: Cosmological imagery
questions.explanation: Verse 22 uses cosmological imagery common in the ancient Near East, depicting God’s sovereign control over the earth and heavens as a cosmic ruler.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 40:29-31 develop the theme of divine strength compared to human weakness?
options: By contrasting human weariness with the strength God gives
By describing the creation of the world
questions.correctAnswer: By contrasting human weariness with the strength God gives
questions.explanation: These verses contrast human fatigue with God’s empowering strength, especially for those who wait on the LORD, symbolizing spiritual renewal.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 40:11 portrays God as a shepherd who gently leads and carries the lambs in His bosom.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:11 uses shepherd imagery to depict God's caring and protective nature toward His people, highlighting His tender leadership.

questions.question: In Isaiah 40:15, the nations are described as "a drop of a bucket" and "small dust of the balance." What does this metaphor convey about the nations relative to God?
options: Their insignificance compared to God’s greatness
questions.correctAnswer: Their insignificance compared to God’s greatness
questions.explanation: This metaphor emphasizes the minuscule status of nations when measured against God's immense power and majesty.

questions.question: Isaiah 40:19-20 critiques idol worship. What cultural practice of the ancient Near East does this passage specifically address?
options: Crafting and worship of graven images
questions.correctAnswer: Crafting and worship of graven images
questions.explanation: Verses 19-20 describe the making and adorning of idols with gold and silver, addressing the common practice of idol worship in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: What is the significance of the repeated phrase "Behold your God!" in Isaiah 40:9 in the context of Israel’s history and hope?
options: It announces the coming of God to redeem and restore Israel
It calls for Israel to build temples
It predicts the fall of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: It announces the coming of God to redeem and restore Israel
questions.explanation: Verse 9 is a call to proclaim God’s imminent arrival as a redeemer, promising comfort and restoration after exile.

questions.question: Which theme in Isaiah 40 reflects a significant development in the biblical understanding of God's transcendence compared to earlier chapters?
options: God’s sovereignty over creation and nations
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereignty over creation and nations
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40 emphasizes God’s absolute control over the cosmos and history, highlighting His transcendence beyond idols and earthly powers.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 40:27-28 address the concerns of Israel regarding God's apparent absence or inactivity?
options: By affirming God's everlasting nature and unsearchable understanding
By instructing Israel to build altars
questions.correctAnswer: By affirming God's everlasting nature and unsearchable understanding
questions.explanation: These verses respond to Israel’s doubt by emphasizing God’s eternal strength and wisdom, reassuring that He is neither faint nor weary.

questions.question: The imagery of "mounting up with wings as eagles" in Isaiah 40:31 serves as a metaphor for what spiritual reality?
questions.correctAnswer: Renewed strength and divine empowerment
questions.explanation: The eagle imagery symbolizes the revitalizing power God grants to those who rely on Him, enabling endurance beyond natural human limits.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 40:16, Lebanon and its animals are sufficient to offer as burnt offerings to God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:16 states that Lebanon is not sufficient for a burnt offering, indicating that no earthly sacrifice can match God’s greatness.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 40 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 40 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 40, what is the primary message God commands to be proclaimed to His people?
options: Prepare ye the way of the LORD
Lift up thy voice with strength
questions.correctAnswer: Comfort ye my people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:1 initiates the chapter with God commanding comfort for His people, emphasizing His mercy and restoration, which is consistent with God's nature as a comforter (2 Corinthians 1:3-4; Psalm 34:18; John 14:27; Revelation 21:4).

questions.question: In Isaiah 40:3, what is the role of 'the voice crying in the wilderness'?
options: Prepare ye the way of the LORD
Behold the glory of the LORD
Lift up your eyes on high
questions.correctAnswer: Prepare ye the way of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:3 speaks prophetically about preparing the way for God’s coming, a theme fulfilled in the New Testament with John the Baptist (Matthew 3:3; Mark 1:3; Luke 3:4; John 1:23).

questions.question: What imagery does Isaiah 40 use to describe God's care for His people?
options: He shall feed his flock like a shepherd
He shall rule with an iron scepter
He shall build a mighty tower
He shall cast fire upon His enemies
questions.correctAnswer: He shall feed his flock like a shepherd
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:11 depicts God’s shepherd-like care, emphasizing tenderness and protection, echoing Psalm 23:1-4, John 10:11, Ezekiel 34:11, and Hebrews 13:20.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 40:8 declare about the word of God?
options: The word of our God shall stand forever
The word of God is like grass that withers
The word of God fades like a flower
The word of God is hidden and obscure
questions.correctAnswer: The word of our God shall stand forever
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:8 contrasts the temporality of creation with the eternal nature of God's word, consistent with Matthew 24:35, 1 Peter 1:25, Psalm 119:89, and Hebrews 4:12.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 40:12 describe God's sovereignty over creation?
options: He measures the waters in the hollow of His hand
He sleeps and forgets the world
He is limited by the heavens
He is aided by angels in creation
questions.correctAnswer: He measures the waters in the hollow of His hand
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes God's unlimited power and control over creation, paralleling Job 38:4-11, Psalm 104:5-9, Jeremiah 10:12, and Colossians 1:16-17.

questions.question: What rhetorical question does Isaiah 40 repeatedly ask to emphasize God's uniqueness?
options: To whom then will ye liken God?
What god can compare with idols?
Who can follow the ways of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: To whom then will ye liken God?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:18 and 40:25 ask this to highlight God's incomparable nature, resonating with Exodus 15:11, Deuteronomy 4:35, Psalm 89:6, and Jeremiah 10:6.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 40:22, how is God depicted in relation to the earth and heavens?
options: He sitteth upon the circle of the earth
He dwells in the temple of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: He sitteth upon the circle of the earth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:22 presents a majestic image of God's sovereign rule over the earth and heavens, consistent with Job 26:7-10, Psalm 103:11, Proverbs 8:27, and Acts 17:24.

questions.question: What attribute of God is highlighted in Isaiah 40:28 regarding His power and knowledge?
options: The everlasting God neither faints nor is weary
God is limited and needs counsel
God is subject to human understanding
questions.correctAnswer: The everlasting God neither faints nor is weary
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:28 emphasizes God's eternal strength and infinite wisdom, corroborated by Psalm 147:5, Jeremiah 23:24, Romans 11:33, and Hebrews 4:13.

questions.question: What promise does Isaiah 40:31 give to those who wait upon the LORD?
options: They shall renew their strength and mount up with wings as eagles
They shall be cast down like stubble
questions.correctAnswer: They shall renew their strength and mount up with wings as eagles
questions.explanation: This verse promises divine empowerment for the faithful, echoing Psalm 103:5, 2 Corinthians 12:9, Philippians 4:13, and Hebrews 12:1-2.

questions.question: Isaiah 40:6-7 uses the metaphor 'All flesh is grass.' What theological truth does this convey?
options: Human life is transient and frail
questions.correctAnswer: Human life is transient and frail
questions.explanation: These verses illustrate human mortality and the temporary nature of earthly glory, as supported by Psalm 103:15-16, James 1:10-11, 1 Peter 1:24, and Job 14:1.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 40:15 teach about the nations compared to God?
options: Nations are like a drop in a bucket to God
Nations are equal to God in power
Nations are the foundation of God's kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: Nations are like a drop in a bucket to God
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes God's overwhelming sovereignty and the insignificance of nations compared to Him, consistent with Psalm 33:8-9, Daniel 4:35, Romans 9:20-21, and Revelation 4:11.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 40:9 describe Zion's role in proclaiming God's message?
options: Bring good tidings and lift up thy voice with strength
questions.correctAnswer: Bring good tidings and lift up thy voice with strength
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:9 calls Zion to announce God's salvation boldly, paralleling Romans 10:15, Psalm 40:9, 2 Corinthians 5:20, and Isaiah 52:7.

questions.question: What is the significance of the question in Isaiah 40:13, 'Who hath directed the Spirit of the LORD?'
options: It highlights God's sovereignty and that no one counsels Him
It teaches that God is limited by the Spirit
It shows the Spirit is independent of God
It suggests angels direct God's Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights God's sovereignty and that no one counsels Him
questions.explanation: This rhetorical question underscores God's absolute authority and independence, supported by Job 33:4, Psalm 104:30, John 3:8, and 1 Corinthians 2:10-11.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 40:19-20 reveal about idolatry?
questions.correctAnswer: Idols are man-made and powerless
questions.explanation: These verses criticize the futility of idols, crafted by human hands and unable to save, echoing Psalm 135:15-18, Jeremiah 10:3-5, Habakkuk 2:18-19, and Acts 17:29.

questions.question: In Isaiah 40:10, what two aspects of God’s coming are highlighted?
options: Strong hand and reward with Him
questions.correctAnswer: Strong hand and reward with Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 40:10 portrays God’s powerful and victorious coming, consistent with Exodus 15:6, Psalm 98:1, Revelation 19:11, and Matthew 25:31.
